What changes were made to staking in Verus version X?

Staking now works on all normal ID balances, enabling full use of IDs for storing and staking funds. This means that users can now stake their funds stored in their VerusIDs, allowing for more flexibility and control over their assets.

Note: Replace "Verus version X" with the actual version number.

- Staking will now work on all normal ID balances, enabling full use of IDs for storing and staking funds.- A new “sendcurrency” API for the command line provides more control when sending from and to multiple addresses or identities.- “updateidentity` will now be able to change the case of characters in the name of a VerusID in the global locale.- Revocation identity will now lose all control over an ID after revocation, including the ability to still change the revocation identity itself, which it used to retain. After revocation now, the recovery identity will have full control over the revoked ID.- Staking and hashing consensus protocol updates with VerusHash 2.2## New in v0.7.0-4
- Validate ID destination on `sendfrom`, `sendtoaddress`, `sendmany`, and `z_sendmany`# DisclaimerThis is experimental and unfinished software. Use at your own risk! No warranty for any kind of damage!

How does the "updateidentity" command handle changes to the name of a VerusID?

The "updateidentity" command can now change the case of characters in the name of a VerusID in the global locale. This means that users can update their VerusID names to reflect changes in case, such as changing from uppercase to lowercase or vice versa.

What changes were made to the revocation identity process in a recent version of Verus?

After revocation, the revocation identity will now lose all control over an ID, including the ability to still change the revocation identity itself. The recovery identity will have full control over the revoked ID. This means that the revocation process is more secure and prevents the revocation identity from retaining control over the ID.
